awd_titl_txt: SaTC:EDU: Enhancing Security Education in Hybrid Mobile and Internet of Things Firmware through Inclusive, Engaging, Learning Modules (E-SHIIELD)
awd_abstract_narration:
Improvements in advanced cybersecurity education are necessary to strengthen the nation’s cybersecurity workforce, including efforts to ensure diversity in the cybersecurity workforce. This project has two overarching goals:  (1) to develop curricular materials  relating to web-based (hybrid) mobile apps and Internet of Things (IoT) firmware security, and (2) to strengthen the nation's workforce, especially for current and future generation students from underrepresented groups. Toward the above goals, this project will create and broadly deploy two courses in the web-based mobile app and IoT security technology spaces. The courses will incorporate state-of-the-art educational techniques that address challenges that instructors face in teaching these advanced cybersecurity topics. Using multiple methods of instruction and rapidly-changing course materials, the faculty will employ inclusive and engaged educational strategies for promoting diversity in advanced cybersecurity.
 
The primary goals of this project are to develop, deploy, evaluate and disseminate course modules in the areas of hybrid mobile apps and IoT firmware security. The courses will be designed as stackable modules for easy integration into existing courses, and broadly disseminated under a Creative Commons license. Additionally, the courses will be designed to align with NSA/DHS Centers for Academic Excellence (CAE) Knowledge Unit requirements to incentivize CAE institutions to adopt them. The scope of the course modules will range from junior and senior level undergraduate courses to graduate level courses. Modules will target students pursuing various degree programs in cybersecurity at the University of North Carolina at Charlotte (UNCC) and extend more broadly to students pursuing Computer Science degrees at UNCC and other institutions. Specifically, the project will train faculty at five North Carolina universities (including HBCUs and community colleges) on the course modules, to deploy them at their universities. The project will also include a K-12 IoT Roadshow at five Title I Charlotte-Mecklenburg Schools. The course modules will adopt the Inclusive Curriculum Framework and mploy state-of-the-art educational strategies aimed towards improved student learning and engagement. Modules will support multiple class modalities (face-to-face, hybrid, online). The course modules will also ensure accessibility and inclusivity in the concept, content, delivery, assessment, feedback and review.  

This project is supported by the Secure and Trustworthy Cyberspace (SaTC) program, which funds proposals that address cybersecurity and privacy, and in this case specifically cybersecurity education. The SaTC program aligns with the Federal Cybersecurity Research and Development Strategic Plan and the National Privacy Research Strategy to protect and preserve the growing social and economic benefits of cyber systems while ensuring security and privacy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Summary

This project aims to address the growing cybersecurity workforce gap by developing innovative curriculum and training programs in the areas of web-based mobile app and IoT firmware security. By focusing on inclusive and engaging teaching strategies, the project seeks to attract and retain a diverse group of students in cybersecurity.

Major Accomplishments:

  1. DISSAV: A Program Visualization Tool for Teaching Stack Smashing Attacks

    • Enables students to construct and execute stack smashing attack scenarios through customizable programs and dynamic payloads, enhancing hands-on learning.

    • Provides interactive visual representations of the call stack, stack frames, and program code, making complex cybersecurity concepts more accessible.

    • Achieves a high level of learner engagement by integrating constructing tasks, recognized as one of the most effective forms of educational interaction.

  2. Stack Smashing Module:  A sequence of guided-learning activities developed to teach concepts that relate to stack smashing attacks that include:

    • A software security module with four Process-Oriented Guided Inquiry Learning (POGIL)-style activities, covering buffer overflows, process memory layout, stack smashing, and defenses, enabling students to build foundational knowledge incrementally.

    • Process-oriented tasks that improve students' critical thinking and information processing skills, while teaching them to recognize vulnerabilities and calculate attack payloads effectively.

    • Deployment of the module in multiple undergraduate cybersecurity courses, receiving positive feedback on activity clarity, progression, and targeted learning outcomes.

    • Two POGIL-certified Activities:

      1. POGIL Activity Clearinghouse: Ramaprasad, H., Sridhar, M., & Snyder, Y. (2024). Activity 3: Stack Smashing. POGIL Activity Clearinghouse, 2(3).

      2. POGIL Activity Clearinghouse: Ramaprasad, H., Sridhar, M., & Snyder, Y. (2024). Activity 4: Defenses. POGIL Activity Clearinghouse, 2(3).

  3. Criminal Investigations: An interactive, gamified web-based framework to teach and assess cybersecurity

    • Involves innovative teaching strategies, such as gamification and interactive learning activities, to motivate and engage students.

    • Creates inclusive learning environments that cater to diverse student needs and learning styles.

  4. Neurodiversity research:
  • Deployed and evaluated the effectiveness of a software security module for neurodivergent students with ASD and ADHD, promoting inclusivity in advanced cybersecurity education.
  • Recruited 9 participants from the AccessComputing group, with preliminary findings showing positive learning outcomes and high student engagement, demonstrating the module's effectiveness and accessibility for neurodivergent learners.

  • Identified areas for improvement including phrasing of activity questions better, and technical refinements.

  1. Class sourced penetration testing:
  • Implemented a flipped classroom model with pre-class preparation, interactive quizzes, and six weeks of hands-on activities, providing students with practical experience in IoT device penetration testing.

  • Designed a three-phase module covering network security (OpenWrt setup and Linux firewalls), web security (XSS and CSRF vulnerability testing), and software security (buffer-overflow exploitation).

  • Identified and reported two CVEs—CVE-2019-17367 (Cross-Site Request Forgery) and CVE-2019-18992 (Cross-Site Scripting)—through hands-on student projects, demonstrating real-world impact.

  1. XSS Module:

    • The XSS module provides an interactive learning experience with videos, quizzes, and hands-on activities to teach Cross-Site Scripting concepts effectively.

    • It is deployed in graduate and undergraduate courses, emphasizing practical application through identifying vulnerabilities in hybrid mobile apps.

All these activities/modules have been converted into Canvas modules.

Impact and Broader Implications:

  • Enhanced Cybersecurity Workforce: The project has contributed to the development of a more skilled and diverse cybersecurity workforce by equipping students with the necessary knowledge and skills.

  • Improved Cybersecurity Education: The innovative curriculum and teaching strategies have elevated the quality of cybersecurity education at participating institutions.

  • Increased Cybersecurity Awareness: The project has raised awareness of cybersecurity challenges and the importance of cybersecurity education among students, faculty, and the broader community.

Dissemination and Outreach:

We have disseminated our research findings through:

  • Publications in ACM SIGCSE 2022, CISSE 2022, CISSE 2023, IEE FIE 2024.

  • Posters presented at ACM SIGCSE 2021, IEEE SafeThings 2020, ACM SIGCSE 2025.

In addition to the above mentioned conferences, below are few other meetings / presentations.

  • Presented at CS Research Day 2024

  • Presented at SATC PI Meeting

  • Presented at CEIR Research

  • Collaborations: Partnerships with industry and academic institutions.

  • Open-Source Software: Development and release of an open-source stack smashing attack visualization tool, DISSAV, for the software security community. 

  • Shared course materials and best practices through open-source repositories and online platforms.

  • Presented research findings at conferences and workshops.
